meenalbindal: Hi @tahirakashyap ...it's so cajoling n inspiring to see women who have faced the scare of the big C n have come out of it has warriors..I am one of them too..really good to see u back to ur gyming...my diagnosis n treatment happened last year n my initial strength at the gym was zero...but today after 6 months on the floor I m strong...you are very strong n will reach ur target soon...lots of sunshine to u.
muhammedayaankhan: Mam my advice is that don't do ego lifting.. everyone has their ability to lift.. A part from that you have gone through surgery soo lift light weights only... slow and steadily you can increase your weights... all of the sudden don't go to heavy weight .. im saying this with my experience as im in a fitness field since last 10years ... may god bless you with good health and soon recovery.. all the best
dr.ravi.patel: C. Yes weight matters when lifting, but optimal form is more important check out my post regards to shoulder and chest workouts. I would recommend having your set done at 40-45 degrees instead of 0 degrees. You are prone to shoulder injury with that form at 0 degrees. Just thought I should let you know. Keep working out 💪🏼 Cheers💯
bhangrababies: @tahirakashyap I’m a survivor myself stage 3 that too, you can go beyond 5 kgs on the surgery arm, the only thing is that it eventually starts to weigh you down. Irrespective of what the doctors say or said post my surgery, I still picked both my kids who were 2 years and 8 months at the time weighing a whole lot more than 5 kgs The body adjusts accordingly give it time and nothing like yoga and exercise to get the flow going. Wishing you health, happiness and love always ❤️
